documentation:
AWS Data Exchange is a service that makes it easy for AWS customers to exchange data in the cloud. You can use the AWS Data Exchange APIs to create, update, manage, and access file-based data set in the AWS Cloud.

As a subscriber, you can view and access the data sets that you have an entitlement to through a subscription. You can use the APIS to download or copy your entitled data sets to Amazon S3 for use across a variety of AWS analytics and machine learning services.

As a provider, you can create and manage your data sets that you would like to publish to a product. Being able to package and provide your data sets into products requires a few steps to determine eligibility. For more information, visit the AWS Data Exchange User Guide.

A data set is a collection of data that can be changed or updated over time. Data sets can be updated using revisions, which represent a new version or incremental change to a data set. A revision contains one or more assets. An asset in AWS Data Exchange is a piece of data that can be stored as an Amazon S3 object. The asset can be a structured data file, an image file, or some other data file. Jobs are asynchronous import or export operations used to create or copy assets.

CancelJob.documentation: This operation cancels a job. Jobs can be cancelled only when they are in the WAITING state.
CancelJob.name: CancelJob

CreateRevision.documentation: This operation creates a revision for a data set.
CreateRevision.name: CreateRevision

GetAsset.documentation: This operation returns information about an asset.
GetAsset.name: GetAsset

GetDataSet.documentation: This operation returns information about a data set.
GetDataSet.name: GetDataSet

GetJob.documentation: This operation returns information about a job.
GetJob.name: GetJob

GetRevision.documentation: This operation returns information about a revision.
GetRevision.name: GetRevision

ListDataSetRevisions.documentation: This operation lists a data set's revisions sorted by CreatedAt in descending order.
ListDataSetRevisions.name: ListDataSetRevisions

ListDataSets.documentation: This operation lists your data sets. When listing by origin OWNED, results are sorted by CreatedAt in descending order. When listing by origin ENTITLED, there is no order and the maxResults parameter is ignored.
ListDataSets.name: ListDataSets

ListJobs.documentation: This operation lists your jobs sorted by CreatedAt in descending order.
ListJobs.name: ListJobs

ListRevisionAssets.documentation: This operation lists a revision's assets sorted alphabetically in descending order.
ListRevisionAssets.name: ListRevisionAssets

ListTagsForResource.documentation: This operation lists the tags on the resource.
ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource

UntagResource.documentation: This operation removes one or more tags from a resource.
UntagResource.name: UntagResource

Arn.documentation: An Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an AWS resource.

Bucket.documentation: The S3 bucket that is the destination for the asset.

Key.documentation: The name of the object in Amazon S3 for the asset.

AssetEntry.documentation: An asset in AWS Data Exchange is a piece of data that can be stored as an S3 object. The asset can be a structured data file, an image file, or some other data file. When you create an import job for your files, you create an asset in AWS Data Exchange for each of those files.

AssetDetails.documentation: Information about the asset, including its size.

AssetType.documentation: The type of file your data is stored in. Currently, the supported asset type is S3_SNAPSHOT.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the asset was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this asset.

Name.documentation: The name of the asset. When importing from Amazon S3, the S3 object key is used as the asset name. When exporting to Amazon S3, the asset name is used as default target S3 object key.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision associated with this asset.

SourceId.documentation: The asset ID of the owned asset corresponding to the entitled asset being viewed. This parameter is returned when an asset owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned asset.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the asset was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

AssetName.documentation: The name of the asset. When importing from Amazon S3, the S3 object key is used as the asset name. When exporting to Amazon S3, the asset name is used as default target S3 object key.

Bucket.documentation: The S3 bucket that's part of the source of the asset.

Key.documentation: The name of the object in Amazon S3 for the asset.

AssetType.documentation: The type of file your data is stored in. Currently, the supported asset type is S3_SNAPSHOT.

ConflictException.documentation: The request couldn't be completed because it conflicted with the current state of the resource.

Message.documentation: The request couldn't be completed because it conflicted with the current state of the resource.

ResourceId.documentation: The unique identifier for the resource with the conflict.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of the resource with the conflict.

AssetType.documentation: The type of file your data is stored in. Currently, the supported asset type is S3_SNAPSHOT.

Description.documentation: A description for the data set. This value can be up to 16,348 characters long.

Tags.documentation: A data set tag is an optional label that you can assign to a data set when you create it. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. When you use tagging, you can also use tag-based access control in IAM policies to control access to these data sets and revisions.

AssetType.documentation: The type of file your data is stored in. Currently, the supported asset type is S3_SNAPSHOT.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the data set was created, in ISO 8601 format.

Id.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set.

Origin.documentation: A property that defines the data set as OWNED by the account (for providers) or ENTITLED to the account (for subscribers).

OriginDetails.documentation: If the origin of this data set is ENTITLED, includes the details for the product on AWS Marketplace.

SourceId.documentation: The data set ID of the owned data set corresponding to the entitled data set being viewed. This parameter is returned when a data set owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned data set.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the data set was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

Type.documentation: The type of job to be created.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the job was created, in ISO 8601 format.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the job was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for a data set.

Tags.documentation: A revision tag is an optional label that you can assign to a revision when you create it. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. When you use tagging, you can also use tag-based access control in IAM policies to control access to these data sets and revisions.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this revision.

Finalized.documentation:
To publish a revision to a data set in a product, the revision must first be finalized. Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that your changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products.

Finalized revisions can be published through the AWS Data Exchange console or the AWS Marketplace Catalog API, using the StartChangeSet AWS Marketplace Catalog API action. When using the API, revisions are uniquely identified by their ARN.

SourceId.documentation: The revision ID of the owned revision corresponding to the entitled revision being viewed. This parameter is returned when a revision owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned revision.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

Finalized.documentation:
To publish a revision to a data set in a product, the revision must first be finalized. Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that your changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products.

Finalized revisions can be published through the AWS Data Exchange console or the AWS Marketplace Catalog API, using the StartChangeSet AWS Marketplace Catalog API action. When using the API, revisions are uniquely identified by their ARN.

ImportAssetFromSignedUrlRequestDetails.documentation: Details of the operation to be performed by the job.

AssetName.documentation: The name of the asset. When importing from Amazon S3, the S3 object key is used as the asset name.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this import job.

Md5Hash.documentation: The Base64-encoded Md5 hash for the asset, used to ensure the integrity of the file at that location.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision associated with this import request.

ImportAssetFromSignedUrlResponseDetails.documentation: The details in the response for an import request, including the signed URL and other information.

AssetName.documentation: The name for the asset associated with this import response.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this import job.

Md5Hash.documentation: The Base64-encoded Md5 hash for the asset, used to ensure the integrity of the file at that location.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision associated with this import response.

SignedUrlExpiresAt.documentation: The time and date at which the signed URL expires, in ISO 8601 format.

ImportAssetsFromS3RequestDetails.documentation: Details of the operation to be performed by the job.

AssetSources.documentation: Is a list of S3 bucket and object key pairs.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this import job.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision associated with this import request.

ImportAssetsFromS3ResponseDetails.documentation: Details from an import from Amazon S3 response.

AssetSources.documentation: Is a list of Amazon S3 bucket and object key pairs.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this import job.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision associated with this import response.

InternalServerException.documentation: An exception occurred with the service.

Message.documentation: The message identifying the service exception that occurred.

JobEntry.documentation: AWS Data Exchange Jobs are asynchronous import or export operations used to create or copy assets. A data set owner can both import and export as they see fit. Someone with an entitlement to a data set can only export. Jobs are deleted 90 days after they are created.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the job was created, in ISO 8601 format.

Details.documentation: Details of the operation to be performed by the job, such as export destination details or import source details.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the job was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

JobError.documentation: An error that occurred with the job request.

Code.documentation: The code for the job error.

LimitName.documentation: The name of the limit that was reached.

LimitValue.documentation: The value of the exceeded limit.

Message.documentation: The message related to the job error.

ResourceId.documentation: The unqiue identifier for the resource related to the error.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of resource related to the error.

JobErrorLimitName.documentation: The name of the limit that was reached.

JobErrorResourceTypes.documentation: The types of resource which the job error can apply to.

NextToken.documentation: The token value retrieved from a previous call to access the next page of results.

Origin.documentation: A property that defines the data set as OWNED by the account (for providers) or ENTITLED to the account (for subscribers). When an owned data set is published in a product, AWS Data Exchange creates a copy of the data set. Subscribers can access that copy of the data set as an entitled data set.

ExportAssetToSignedUrl.documentation: Details about the export to signed URL request.

ExportAssetsToS3.documentation: Details about the export to Amazon S3 request.

ImportAssetFromSignedUrl.documentation: Details about the import from signed URL request.

ImportAssetsFromS3.documentation: Details about the import from Amazon S3 request.

ResourceId.documentation: The unique identifier for the resource that couldn't be found.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of resource that couldn't be found.

ExportAssetToSignedUrl.documentation: Details for the export to signed URL response.

ExportAssetsToS3.documentation: Details for the export to Amazon S3 response.

ImportAssetFromSignedUrl.documentation: Details for the import from signed URL response.

ImportAssetsFromS3.documentation: Details for the import from Amazon S3 response.

RevisionEntry.documentation: A revision is a container for one or more assets.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this revision.

Finalized.documentation:
To publish a revision to a data set in a product, the revision must first be finalized. Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that your changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products.

Finalized revisions can be published through the AWS Data Exchange console or the AWS Marketplace Catalog API, using the StartChangeSet AWS Marketplace Catalog API action. When using the API, revisions are uniquely identified by their ARN.

SourceId.documentation: The revision ID of the owned revision corresponding to the entitled revision being viewed. This parameter is returned when a revision owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned revision.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

S3SnapshotAsset.documentation: The S3 object that is the asset.

Size.documentation: The size of the S3 object that is the object.

ServiceLimitExceededException.documentation: The request has exceeded the quotas imposed by the service.

LimitName.documentation: The name of the quota that was exceeded.

LimitValue.documentation: The maximum value for the service-specific limit.

Message.documentation: The request has exceeded the quotas imposed by the service.

ResourceArn.documentation: An Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an AWS resource.

Tags.documentation: A label that consists of a customer-defined key and an optional value.

ThrottlingException.documentation: The limit on the number of requests per second was exceeded.

Message.documentation: The limit on the number of requests per second was exceeded.

Timestamp.documentation: Dates and times in AWS Data Exchange are recorded in ISO 8601 format.

To publish a revision to a data set in a product, the revision must first be finalized. Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products.
